quotes.topic_title: AI changing performance marketing work
quotes.text: There's a lot of different ways that we are beginning to use AI to do more with less, basically.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Sets the core practitioner takeaway: AI is being applied to increase output without proportional headcount increases.

quotes.topic_title: AI changing performance marketing work
quotes.text: The effect ultimately that we've seen from a human capital point of view is displacement.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that AI changes what people do (role shift) rather than simply reducing team size.

quotes.topic_title: AI changing performance marketing work
quotes.text: We have more people now than we've ever had, but the nature of the work that they do is more strategic.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights a practical org design implication: keep/increase headcount while reallocating effort toward higher-leverage work.

quotes.topic_title: AI changing performance marketing work
quotes.text: It's more about modeling, validation, asking the right questions, being focused around creative levers.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Provides a clear framework for where humans add value in AI-assisted performance marketing: strategy, QA, and creative direction.

quotes.topic_title: AI changing performance marketing work
quotes.text: On our creative group, we can come up with mockups, in literally, 1% of the time that it took.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A concrete example and data point showing how AI compresses creative iteration cycles and speeds client-facing exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I became pretty obsessed and fascinated with the fact that you could build landing pages or homepages, or whatever it was. Basically the content on a website, and structure it in a manner where you had the chance to surface in organic, so SEO results more prominently.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable mental model: treat page structure/content as a lever you can intentionally design to improve discoverability.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The answers to their questions ended up being a lot more aligned with what then was the biggest driver in the paid acquisition world, which was paid search.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical heuristic for channel strategy: when stakeholders demand ROI and scalability, paid search often maps better to those needs than SEO.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: What I found was that it was a tangible format and lever through which we could basically give people the types of results they were expecting from SEO, but that were obfuscated in terms of Google's analysis algorithm from an organic point of view being somewhat intangible.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterintuitive positioning of paid search as the more controllable/legible way to achieve outcomes people often expect from SEO.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: 10 plus years later, what started off as this freelancer consultancy that I started running in a walk-in closet in my old apartment, became 130 people. And we manage about $500 million a year in ad spend for small and large companies, including Uber, Asana, Tempur-Pedic.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Concrete scale data point that anchors credibility and illustrates what “agency growth” can look like over a decade.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Brain Trust charges a flat rate of only 10%, unlike agency fees of up to 70%, so you can make your budget go four times further.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Concrete cost comparison that can inform a hiring/build-vs-buy decision and budgeting model.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Plus, they're the only network that takes 0% of what the talent makes, so they're able to attract and retain the world's best tech talent.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A counterintuitive incentive design claim: taking less from talent can improve marketplace quality and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Take it from DoorDash, Airbnb, Plaid, and hundreds of other high growth startups that have shaved their hiring process for months to weeks at less than a quarter of the cost by hiring through Brain Trust network of 20,000 high quality vetted candidates ready to work.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Specific social proof plus measurable outcomes (time and cost) that practitioners can benchmark against their own hiring funnel.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Product team that startups and enterprises are using AssemblyAI to automatically transcribe and summarize phone calls and virtual meetings, detect topics in podcasts, pinpoint when sensitive content is spoken, and lots more.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A practical menu of high-leverage AI audio use cases teams can copy into product roadmaps.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So many PMs I know are considering or already building with AI, and AssemblyAI is the fastest way to build with AI for audio use cases.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: A speed-focused build strategy: use an API to ship AI audio features faster than building models in-house.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy story: landing Uber as a client
quotes.text: I think people often talk about entrepreneurs who have been successful and they comment that they're lucky. Whereas, I actually look at that situation and I think that you have to make your own luck.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A clear mental model: luck is something you actively create and capitalize on, not a passive trait.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy story: landing Uber as a client
quotes.text: But I decided to take a risk, being that I could get embarrassed or nothing could happen, or they could shut down this referral gimmicky thing that I was doing. I had very little to lose, I guess, ultimately.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Actionable risk calculus: take shots when downside is limited and upside is meaningful.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy story: landing Uber as a client
quotes.text: But a lot of people just don't make these moves in life because they're nervous, or they're worried too much about what the downside might be.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterpoint to conventional caution—overweighting downside prevents high-upside opportunities.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy story: landing Uber as a client
quotes.text: And you put yourself in situations where everybody has luck, but you have to capitalize on it basically.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical methodology: engineer exposure to opportunity, then act decisively when it appears.

quotes.topic_title: Crazy story: landing Uber as a client
quotes.text: And I ended up making tens of thousands of dollars doing this.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating how exploiting a marketing loophole can produce meaningful results (and surface a consulting opportunity).

quotes.topic_title: What to call paid growth and why
quotes.text: Some people think of those two things as growth marketing, whereas I see growth marketing as a bigger practice area within which paid acquisition sits.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Defines a clear hierarchy of terms that helps teams align on scope and ownership (growth marketing as the umbrella, paid acquisition as a sub-discipline).

quotes.topic_title: What to call paid growth and why
quotes.text: And then of course there's subsets, there's social ads, there's paid search, there's programmatic.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Offers a practical taxonomy for breaking “paid growth” into operational subchannels for planning, hiring, and measurement.

quotes.topic_title: What to call paid growth and why
quotes.text: I'm going to use performance marketing. I like that term because it really describes what it is. It's like marketing with you can measure performance.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Anchors the discipline around measurability, reinforcing a performance/ROI-first mental model for how to run and evaluate paid efforts.

quotes.topic_title: What to call paid growth and why
quotes.text: On the other hand, there's this sense that it's this drug that you start and then you get hooked on and you can never leave.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Captures a contrarian risk model—paid growth can create dependency—useful for thinking about channel mix and long-term sustainability.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth as a 'drug' and diversification
quotes.text: The analogy that I try and use here is that it would be very dangerous if I was advising you with your life savings and I told you to put it all in a single stock in the stock market.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A clear mental model for why betting your growth on one paid channel is inherently risky due to volatility outside your control.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth as a 'drug' and diversification
quotes.text: I don't recommend putting all of your money into a single performance marketing channel, and then somewhat exposing you to the volatility of fluctuating CPCs or changing market conditions.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to diversify spend to reduce exposure to pricing and market swings in any one channel.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth as a 'drug' and diversification
quotes.text: But when I think about the fact that Thrive manages $500 million a year, I think of myself to a extent as a fund manager, we are managing people's money with the expectation of a return.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Reframes performance marketing as capital allocation/portfolio management, not just campaign execution.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth as a 'drug' and diversification
quotes.text: And similarly, I always say to people that the first rule of performance marketing is not to forget about offline marketing and the classic marketing that works for organizations.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterbalances the default “paid-first” mindset by emphasizing a broader channel mix including offline/classic tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Paid growth as a 'drug' and diversification
quotes.text: And what they fail to see is that those loopholes come and go.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Warns against fragile growth “hacks” tied to platform quirks that can disappear and collapse a business built on them.

quotes.topic_title: When paid growth fits: stage, scale, resourcing
quotes.text: Early stage, look at what the company is doing, look at your own company. Have you established product market fit? Is this an idea that has yet to be tested, and are they entirely looking to performance marketing to scale everything? Are they at risk of it becoming an over-reliance on performance marketing?
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A stage-based diagnostic for whether paid growth is appropriate, emphasizing PMF and the risk of over-relying on performance marketing too early.

quotes.topic_title: When paid growth fits: stage, scale, resourcing
quotes.text: The question at a later stage is not, does it work? But, to what scale can it work?
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A memorable reframing that shifts evaluation from channel viability to scalability once a company is beyond early-stage uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: When paid growth fits: stage, scale, resourcing
quotes.text: And so we are looking at things like, do they have adequate creative resources and buy-in? Does creative resourcing tie into performance, and can we create a feedback loop there around testing?
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Actionable criteria for later-stage paid growth success: creative capacity, organizational buy-in, and a structured testing feedback loop.

quotes.topic_title: When paid growth fits: stage, scale, resourcing
quotes.text: If we say, "Hey, tracking and attribution is broken, here's how to solve that." Can you implement it?
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for whether a company has the technical resourcing needed to make performance marketing effective.

quotes.topic_title: When paid growth fits: stage, scale, resourcing
quotes.text: Just as evidence of this, Google, which I think had a down quarter reported sales this week, and it was $70 billion in three months. And Facebook similarly just recorded yesterday evening, and it was $32 billion. That's $100 billion on just Google and Facebook in three months, and the majority of that revenue is from ads.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating the massive scale and broad applicability of paid advertising across companies.

quotes.topic_title: Payback periods, LTV modeling, and lead scoring
quotes.text: It's always nice when there's a quick turnaround on investment and return. And that's wonderful for like D2C or e-commerce style businesses where they're essentially taking the revenue to fuel additional inventory and operating costs.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights why fast payback makes paid growth especially effective in ecommerce/D2C due to reinvesting revenue into the operating flywheel.

quotes.topic_title: Payback periods, LTV modeling, and lead scoring
quotes.text: However, not all businesses work that way. And so, in a B2C or B2B lead generation scenario, we have to undertake pretty sophisticated modeling around these abstract concepts, like lifetime value. Which is difficult, because most businesses are relatively new that we work with, and so the idea of lifetime value is a misnomer. They don't know what that is yet.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterintuitively reframes LTV as often unknowable early on, requiring modeling rather than relying on “known” lifetime value numbers.

quotes.topic_title: Payback periods, LTV modeling, and lead scoring
quotes.text: But we have to model things like LTV to CAC, so cost per acquisition costs versus lifetime value and the period within which the payback occurs.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Provides a practical decision framework for paid growth: evaluate LTV:CAC alongside the payback window, not just CAC alone.

quotes.topic_title: Payback periods, LTV modeling, and lead scoring
quotes.text: You end up getting to a pretty sophisticated place where you can build out things like a lead scoring model, which predictively can determine in a statistically significant way the likelihood that one lead will convert to revenue over another.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Describes an actionable methodology—predictive lead scoring—to make paid acquisition viable even when revenue is delayed.

quotes.topic_title: Payback periods, LTV modeling, and lead scoring
quotes.text: And so there are ways around the slower payback period that still end up being pretty accurate based on what you're bidding on today versus the latent revenue that will be accrued to those campaigns through attribution.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Explains the mental model of bidding on present signals while accounting for delayed (“latent”) revenue via attribution and modeling.

quotes.topic_title: Rules of thumb: PMF, attribution limits, patience
quotes.text: Product market fit.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A blunt rule of thumb that paid acquisition works best once PMF is established.

quotes.topic_title: Rules of thumb: PMF, attribution limits, patience
quotes.text: If other things work, it is highly likely that paid acquisition will work.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: validate demand in other channels before scaling paid.

quotes.topic_title: Rules of thumb: PMF, attribution limits, patience
quotes.text: The issue for most companies is in this incorrect assumption that the data that is provided through paid channels allows you to have full end-to-end understanding of attribution. Which is wrong, it's never been that way.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that perfect attribution is a myth, so decisions must account for measurement limits.

quotes.topic_title: Rules of thumb: PMF, attribution limits, patience
quotes.text: Even if I worked with two hotels in the same city, they would have different results based on the nuances of their budget, their brand, the market that they sit within, the services that they offer, and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A concrete example illustrating why benchmarks and “standard” metrics don’t transfer cleanly across similar businesses.

quotes.topic_title: Rules of thumb: PMF, attribution limits, patience
quotes.text: I think that everything else, the main problem here is that nobody should expect an overnight turnaround with performance marketing.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Sets expectations that performance marketing requires iteration and time rather than immediate results.

quotes.topic_title: Can startups still scale mostly via paid?
quotes.text: Every unicorn from the 2010s era that scale did performance marketing, but not everyone during that time who did performance marketing scaled.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A crisp warning against survivorship bias when evaluating paid-first growth as a scaling strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Can startups still scale mostly via paid?
quotes.text: We had plenty of projects that we worked on that flatlined during that period. And so the sense that there was a period of time where this was easy or it worked on any project is not correct in my opinion.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Reframes the “golden age” narrative by emphasizing that paid growth has always required strong fundamentals and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Can startups still scale mostly via paid?
quotes.text: Grammarly is a really good example of this. They have been good at solving for this problem that exists around understanding the cost per acquisition versus lifetime value, how sticky customers are, predicting how much revenue can come from a customer and backing out into therefore how much we can pay per click and per lead and so on and so forth.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical methodology for scaling paid: model LTV and retention, forecast revenue per customer, then derive allowable CAC bids.

quotes.topic_title: Can startups still scale mostly via paid?
quotes.text: But I think the amplification of that brand really, really gained traction quite recently where now everybody knows what Athletic Greens is, and that's because they're buying loads of ads on TikTok. They're buying loads of ads on other social channels like Facebook. They're investing in podcasting partnerships. But this is all digital paid acquisition.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A concrete modern example of paid-driven scale across multiple channels (TikTok, Facebook, podcasts) to amplify an existing business.

quotes.topic_title: Can startups still scale mostly via paid?
quotes.text: So all of that said, these storms pass. And so when the economy improves, generally speaking, I imagine people will go back to trying to find as much inventory from a pay per click point of view that they can purchase as possible and figuring out the economics of how to do that.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: An operator’s lens on macro cycles: paid channels fluctuate, but the durable edge is continuously re-solving unit economics and inventory access.

quotes.topic_title: What changed recently: privacy, efficiency, measurement rigor
quotes.text: Because they know, they understand how many impressions they'll get and on average what the quality of impression is and how many dollars they can put behind that before it has a cliff in terms of ROI.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights an efficiency-first approach: quantify impression quality and identify spend levels where ROI drops off a cliff.

quotes.topic_title: What changed recently: privacy, efficiency, measurement rigor
quotes.text: I'm not going to really be able to point to this company is really getting it right and I think that you can do that, but it's like saying, a friend of mine who recently on Twitter tweeted this funny thing where he was like, this is the number that I used to win the lottery said every successful founder ever trying to give advice to other founders.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A contrarian warning against copying “successful” companies’ tactics without understanding the underlying conditions that made them work.

quotes.topic_title: What changed recently: privacy, efficiency, measurement rigor
quotes.text: To that extent, there is a bit of a playbook around modern day performance marketing, and that includes everything from really stringent and rigorous creative testing and thinking about that correctly to understanding the subjectivity of attribution and its strengths and weaknesses, doing a lot of work around validity of these campaigns.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Defines a modern performance marketing methodology: rigorous creative testing plus accepting attribution limits and validating measurement.

quotes.topic_title: What changed recently: privacy, efficiency, measurement rigor
quotes.text: Companies that can do those things and then understand their own marketing economics, in other words, quite basically how much can we afford to spend in acquiring a customer on any channel before that acquisition is no longer profitable.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Gives a practical decision rule for channel spend: CAC ceilings by channel based on unit economics and profitability.

quotes.topic_title: What changed recently: privacy, efficiency, measurement rigor
quotes.text: So really focusing on the profitability of the bottom line and not just break net growth, for instance.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Reframes success away from growth metrics toward bottom-line profitability as the governing constraint for performance marketing.

quotes.topic_title: SEO vs paid search: why both matter
quotes.text: When I'm asked a question of should we put money into organic search or paid search? My response is often that they're actually not mutually exclusive to one another. So it's a great idea to do both, and that backs into my strategy of diversification of channels.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Reframes SEO vs. paid as a portfolio decision—diversify channels rather than choosing one.

quotes.topic_title: SEO vs paid search: why both matter
quotes.text: So don't build up exclusively in one area and create volatility within your marketing mix essentially.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Actionable warning to avoid single-channel dependence that can destabilize growth.

quotes.topic_title: SEO vs paid search: why both matter
quotes.text: So one of the things that people really like about performance marketing theoretically is that we can spend a certain amount and then if we're modeling things correctly, we can essentially determine how much revenue is generated from the actions that we took. Finance teams love that, C-suite teams love that, they can build projections, they can budget around it.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Explains why paid search wins internal buy-in: clearer attribution enables forecasting and budgeting.

quotes.topic_title: SEO vs paid search: why both matter
quotes.text: Search engine optimization is different in that the attribution can be tough. It's difficult to determine whether ultimately the actions that you took contributed to a rise in organic traffic. You have to essentially correlate that.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights SEO’s measurement challenge—often correlation-based rather than directly attributable.

quotes.topic_title: SEO vs paid search: why both matter
quotes.text: Google still has to crawl it. They run it through their analysis algorithm, which is comprised of 200 different signals, of which maybe 20 to 30 have been publicly disclosed. So it's a bit of a black box.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Concrete detail on why SEO outcomes are uncertain: ranking depends on many opaque signals.

quotes.topic_title: Creative is the biggest lever now
quotes.text: So when we say creative, we're referring to the assets that power typically visual programmatic or pay per click campaigns on social channels or display networks.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Defines “creative” in practical, execution-level terms so teams align on what to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Creative is the biggest lever now
quotes.text: I think that when we talk about creative as a big lever around efficiency and optimization, the underlying conversation there is that over time our industry has been heavily automated.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Explains why creative has become the primary lever as bidding/targeting optimizations get automated by platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Creative is the biggest lever now
quotes.text: So you can think about this as generating intent at the top of funnel and capturing intent at the bottom of the funnel.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Introduces a funnel-based mental model for structuring creative messaging across stages.

quotes.topic_title: Creative is the biggest lever now
quotes.text: And one of the major pitfalls that we see is that certain brands just dump one homogenous message into all of their targeting. You see the same ad over and over again. It creates banner blindness and it's a total lack of efficiency.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Calls out a common failure mode (repetitive, one-size-fits-all messaging) and its performance consequence.

quotes.topic_title: Creative is the biggest lever now
quotes.text: You have to try and isolate variables, maintain similar conditions across targeting, and then determine which style and feature of an ad performs best at which stage of the funnel versus which audience.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Gives an experimentation methodology for linking performance data to creative iteration.

quotes.topic_title: How to test creatives and examples of unlocks
quotes.text: The only thing being different across those two creative assets is a single variable.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A clean creative-testing methodology: keep everything constant except one variable to isolate causality.

quotes.topic_title: How to test creatives and examples of unlocks
quotes.text: So sometimes the ad-serving algorithms, even when we set up a test structurally in that way, we'll serve one ad a different number of impressions than the other ad, in which case we then have to say, what is a leveling factor that allows us to look at these two ads equally, even though one received dramatically more impressions than the other?
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights a common testing pitfall (uneven delivery) and the need for normalization to compare ads fairly.

quotes.topic_title: How to test creatives and examples of unlocks
quotes.text: But a good example is looking at the click-through rate, which is essentially a ratio or a metric like impressions until conversion, which is a leveling metric that allows us to determine, even though in a scenario where two ads facing the same audience within the same campaign received different numbers of impressions, we can still measure the efficiency or effectiveness of one ad over the other using metrics like that.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: A practical measurement framework: use rate/ratio metrics to evaluate performance when impression volume is imbalanced.

quotes.topic_title: How to test creatives and examples of unlocks
quotes.text: And when you launch those on Instagram back in the day or something like that, what we found is that they would always underperform next to user generated assets.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counterintuitive creative insight: polished brand ads can lose to authentic UGC in performance channels.

quotes.topic_title: How to test creatives and examples of unlocks
quotes.text: That one change resulted in a total unlock of their performance on paid social channels. It would double or triple the ROAS that we were seeing type thing.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Concrete example/data point showing how a small creative tweak (“dog on the couch”) can massively improve ROAS.

quotes.topic_title: Tools for creative testing: mostly in-platform
quotes.text: these days most of the testing that we do is within the channels themselves.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Emphasizes that sophisticated creative testing can often be done directly inside ad platforms rather than via external tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Tools for creative testing: mostly in-platform
quotes.text: The good news here is that you don't necessarily need some exotic tool to do sophisticated creative testing.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Counteracts the common assumption that advanced creative testing requires specialized third-party software.

quotes.topic_title: Tools for creative testing: mostly in-platform
quotes.text: You can do it in platform and you can use the structure that I just kind of outlined as a starting point.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Gives a practical methodology: rely on in-platform testing plus a disciplined structure for measurement and iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Tools for creative testing: mostly in-platform
quotes.text: I keep touching on those two specifically because they're the most advanced in my opinion. They're really powerful.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Points practitioners toward Meta and Google as the most capable platforms for running structured creative tests.

quotes.topic_title: Tools for creative testing: mostly in-platform
quotes.text: Wish is the epitome of the opposite of brand highly polished ads or it's just the most ridiculous looking product with just banners and numbers and prices and crossouts and all kinds of stuff, just anything that would take to get people to click.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Provides a vivid example of high-velocity, performance-driven creative iteration that prioritizes clicks over polish.

quotes.topic_title: Channel strategy: Google/Meta vs TikTok, Amazon, Snap
quotes.text: So when I say Google and I say Facebook, I'm talking about the Google ecosystem of channels inclusive of YouTube. And when I talk about Facebook, I'm talking about Facebook, Instagram, and probably eventually WhatsApp, which I think will probably launch ads later this year.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Clarifies a practical channel-planning mental model: think in ecosystems (Google=YouTube; Meta=Instagram/WhatsApp), not single platforms.

quotes.topic_title: Channel strategy: Google/Meta vs TikTok, Amazon, Snap
quotes.text: Their ads platform kind of reminds me of where Facebook ads was like six, seven years ago. It's not super sophisticated and attribution is not great yet, but you can get cheap CPCs because there's just fewer organizations advertising there.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Explains the tradeoff on TikTok today—cheaper clicks due to less competition, but weaker tooling/measurement—useful for deciding test budgets and expectations.

quotes.topic_title: Channel strategy: Google/Meta vs TikTok, Amazon, Snap
quotes.text: What we see working very nicely on TikTok, by the way, are these founder led brands where the founder is the ambassador and they're doing those handheld videos with their iPhone.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Gives a concrete creative playbook that practitioners can replicate: founder-led, lo-fi, authentic content performs on TikTok.

quotes.topic_title: Channel strategy: Google/Meta vs TikTok, Amazon, Snap
quotes.text: If you are e-comm based, if you're wholesale, retail based, anything direct to consumer, you have to investigate TikTok and try and figure out whether there's a way of promoting your products there, basically.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Actionable channel guidance: TikTok is a must-test for D2C/retail, rather than an optional experiment.

quotes.topic_title: Channel strategy: Google/Meta vs TikTok, Amazon, Snap
quotes.text: The other problem with TikTok is that it's extraordinarily creative, asset dependent, and heavy. And so you are launching net new assets several times per week, it is hard for creative teams and brands to produce that much content.
quotes.speaker: Jonathan Becker
quotes.context: Highlights the hidden operational cost of TikTok (creative throughput), which often determines whether scaling is feasible.
